docs.lead_paragraph: Government and hospital officials in New York State praised the Supreme Court's decision to strike down the President's line item veto power today, saying it would preserve a set of state hospital taxes that help finance health care for the poor. The decision settles in New York's favor a longstanding disagreement between the state and Federal Government over the legality of some of those taxes, which raised $2.6 billion for health care programs from 1992 to 1996.

headline.main: State and Hospitals Exult in Court's Decision

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday, only six weeks after India conducted nuclear tests, prompting economic sanctions by the United States, the World Bank resumed its lending program to New Delhi with the endorsement of the Clinton Administration. Washington said the aid, $543 million in loans, is chiefly humanitarian and thus exempt from its sanctions.

headline.main: U.S. Allows An Exception In Supporting Loan for India

docs.snippet: Yesterday, only six weeks after India conducted nuclear tests, prompting economic sanctions by the United States, the World Bank resumed its lending program to New Delhi with the endorsement of the Clinton Administration.     Washington said the aid,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Paul O'Dwyer, a spirited liberal voice in New York politics from his immigrant days in the Democratic clubhouse to his glory years as a fiery anti-Vietnam War insurgent, died Tuesday night at his home in Goshen, N.Y. He was 90. Mr. O'Dwyer had been in failing health from the effects of a stroke and died quietly in his sleep, according to his nephew and law partner, Frank Durkan.

headline.main: Paul O'Dwyer, New York's Liberal Battler For Underdogs and Outsiders, Dies at 90

docs.abstract: Paul O'Dwyer, spirited liberal voice in New York politics from his immigrant days in Democratic clubhouse to his glory years as fiery anti-Vietnam War insurgent, dies at age 90; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors said today that two strikes in Michigan that have crippled its car and truck production were illegal, taking an unusually hard stance against its national union over local walkouts. The company said in a statement that it would seek to take the United Automobile Workers to expedited arbitration and wanted a response from the union within 48 hours. The company also plans to block payments of unemployment benefits to idled workers. G.M. tried a similar tactic in a 1996 strike in Dayton, Ohio, but almost all states granted unemployment benefits.

headline.main: G.M. Calls Strikes Illegal and Threatens Jobless Benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans today unveiled a long-awaited proposal to define patients' rights and set uniform nationwide standards for health insurance, especially health maintenance organizations. The insurance industry immediately denounced the plan, saying it would increase costs for consumers. The House Republicans, who have been working behind closed doors for four months on legislation to address voters' anger at the constraints of managed health care, found themselves in the same position as President Clinton four years ago: in the cross hairs of the insurance industry.

headline.main: G.O.P. Unveils A Bill to Define Patients' Rights

docs.abstract: House Republicans unveil long-awaited proposal to define patients' rights and set uniform nationwide standards for health insurance, especially health maintenance organizations; plan, devised by 15-member group headed by Rep Dennis Hastert, would guarantee coverage of emergency medical care, assure open communication between doctors and patients, and allow women in health maintenance organizations to go directly to obstetricians and gynecologists, without prior approval; insurance industry attacks plan; Democratic Congressional leaders say plan does not go far enough; Clinton Administration aides, including Rahm I Emanuel and Labor Sec Alexis Herman welcome it; conservative Senate Republicans cite doubts; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Former China Party Chief Calls for Official Apology Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989, has challenged China's leaders to admit that the incident was not only morally wrong but also an immense political blunder. Mr. Zhao argued that President Clinton's visit to China offered a chance to reverse the official verdict on the massacre. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the disk jockeys on the old Top 40 radio stations who shouted, ''And the hits just keep on coming!''? Well, the rosy predictions for domestic advertising spending just keep on coming from a leading industry forecaster. Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at the McCann-Erickson USA unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, said yesterday that he would again raise his estimate of spending for 1998. The reason: myriad signs of economic growth that have been more robust than anticipated.

headline.main: Billion here, billion there, and soon your estimate on 1998 U.S. ad spending reaches $200.3 billion.

docs.abstract: Robert J Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson USA unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, says he will again raise his estimate of ad spending for 1998; Coen predicts marketers will spend record $200.3 billion in US, up 6.8 percent from revised figure of $187.5 billion for 1997 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about insurance coverage for Viagra misstated Medicaid policy on paying for it. Federal officials have said they expect to require Medicaid payments for Viagra, not deny them, when a doctor says the drug is medically necessary.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 20 article; Federal officials expect to require Medicaid payments for Viagra, not deny them, when doctor says drug is medically necessary

docs.lead_paragraph: For Bernard Gilkey, it was about time. The Mets' left fielder has endured a testing month. One at-bat after snapping an 0-for-25 slide on June 12, Gilkey was hit in the face with a fastball by Ryan Dempster of the Florida Marlins. After singling in his first at-bat back nine days later, Gilkey went 0 for 9. That made him 2 for 36 when he stepped to the plate with two out and two Mets on in the seventh inning tonight against the Baltimore Orioles.

headline.main: Double by Gilkey Lifts The Mets Out of Slump

docs.abstract: New York Mets beat Baltimore Orioles, 6-3; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration's new Medicare regulations will provide important consumer protections for 38 million elderly and disabled beneficiaries as more of them move into the managed-care system. Given Medicare's size and reach, these regulations could also set an operating standard for the rest of the health insurance industry. By moving aggressively to protect Medicare recipients, President Clinton has seized on a powerful political issue. Republicans who have opposed consumer protections for the millions covered by private insurance must now explain why they would deny working families the safeguards that publicly funded Medicare patients will enjoy.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Clinton Administration's new Medicare regulations will provide important consumer protections for 38 million elderly and disabled beneficiaries as more of them move into managed-care system; says Republicans who have opposed consumer protections for the millions covered by private insurance must now explain why they would deny working families safeguards that publicly funded Medicare patients enjoy; says Administration's approach could have positive effect on managed-care system, but more needs to be done (M)
